'Orion Multi-Purpose Crew Vehicle' ('MPCV') is a planned beyond-low-Earth-orbit
manned spacecraft that is being built by Lockheed Martin for NASA and Astrium
for European Space Agency http://www.esa.int/Our_Activities/Human_Spaceflig-
ht/Research/ESA_workhorse_to_power_NASA_s_Orion_spacecraft for crewed
missions to the Moon, asteroids and Mars. It is planned to be launched by the
Space Launch System. Each Orion spacecraft is projected to
carry a crew of up to four or more astronauts. It is also
planned as a backup for ISS cargo and crew
delivery. [http://www.nasa.gov/exploration/systems/mpcv/index.html Orion -
NASA]

The MPCV was announced by NASA on 24 May 2011, aided by
designs and tests already completed for a spacecraft of the cancelled
Constellation program, development for which began in 2005 as the Crew
Exploration Vehicle. It was formerly going to be launched by the tested-but-
cancelled Ares I launch vehicle.

The MPCV's debut unmanned multi-hour test flight, known as Exploration Flight
Test 1 (EFT-1), is scheduled for a launch aboard a Delta IV Heavy rocket in
2014. http://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2011/08/oft-1-
nasa-orions-2013-debut-via-delta-iv-heavy/ http://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2011/10/nasa-managers-serious-
atv-role-as-orion-service-module/ The first manned mission is expected to
take place after 2020. In January 2013, ESA and NASA announced that
the Orion Service Module will be built by European space company Astrium for
European Space Agency. [http://www.nasa.gov/exploration/systems/mp-
cv/orion_feature_011613.html NASA Signs Agreement for a European-Provided Orion
Service Module]
